title: RL33284
content: The federal government has long supported minority and economically disadvantaged small businesses through procurement contracts and assistance programs. These initiatives, originating from the Small Business Act of 1958, aim to promote the development of disadvantaged business enterprises (DBEs) by providing preferential treatment in government contract awards. The § 8(a) program, initially focused on job creation in low-income areas, shifted to minority small business development under President Nixon's executive orders. This program, established in 1978 by P.L. 95-507, aimed to assist minority businesses through federal contracting opportunities. The Small Business Administration's Section 8(a) program allows for government contracts to be subcontracted to socially disadvantaged individuals, including minorities like Blacks, Hispanics, Native Americans, and Asian Pacific Americans. Applicants must demonstrate social disadvantage to qualify for the program. The Small Business Administration's Section 8(a) program allows government contracts to be subcontracted to socially disadvantaged individuals, including minorities. Applicants must establish social and economic disadvantage to qualify for certification. The program includes a presumption of disadvantaged status for minority group members and excludes businesses owned by individuals not truly socially or economically disadvantaged. The Section 8(d) program requires prime contractors on federal contracts to negotiate subcontracting plans with percentage goals for small socially and economically disadvantaged firms. Failure to comply may result in liquidated damages. P.L. 95-507 mandated federal agencies to establish annual goals for awarding contracts to small disadvantaged businesses. The Business Opportunity Development Reform Act of 1988 directed federal agencies to establish annual procurement goals for small disadvantaged businesses, with a government-wide goal of at least 20% for small businesses and 5% for disadvantaged businesses. The goals aim to create maximum opportunity for small disadvantaged businesses to sell goods and services to the government, with waivers allowed in certain circumstances. Amendments in 1994 expanded the minority procurement goal to include small businesses owned by women. "Goals and set-asides for socially and economically disadvantaged individuals, women, and minority groups have been included in federal funding measures for education, defense, and transportation over the last two decades. Congress established participation goals for small disadvantaged businesses in procurement for various agencies and enacted laws with minority business participation goals on federally funded projects." The Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century (TEA-21) and other federal funding measures have included minority business participation goals. Congress authorized agencies to apply a price evaluation preference to bids from businesses other than Small Disadvantaged Businesses (SDBs) to meet these goals. Litigation on racial preferences in federal contracting has been complex since the Supreme Court's decision in Adarand Constructors Inc. v. Pena. The Supreme Court's actions on the Adarand case in 2001 involved changes in legal standing, details of the federal program, and regulatory reforms on affirmative action. The Court dismissed the appeal as "improvidently granted" regarding the Tenth Circuit's ruling on a federal highway program promoting minority business utilization. The program was found to be constitutional after revisions in 1997. This case followed previous Supreme Court decisions on racial preferences in federal contracting. The Supreme Court's decisions in Fullilove v. Klutznick and City of Richmond v. J.A. Croson Co. addressed affirmative action measures for minority entrepreneurs in public contracting. The Court ruled that race-conscious remedies could be legislated in response to past discrimination, but racial balancing without specific evidence of minority exclusion was impermissible. The Adarand case in 2001 applied strict scrutiny to federal programs using racial preferences in contracting. The Adarand case in 2001 applied "strict scrutiny" to a federal transportation program of financial incentives for prime contractors who subcontracted to firms owned by socially and economically disadvantaged group members. The program did not set aside a specific percentage of subcontract awards for disadvantaged business enterprises (DBEs) but provided incentive payments to prime contractors whose subcontracts with DBEs exceeded 10% of the total contract value. The Adarand case in 2001 involved a federal transportation program that paid prime contractors 1.5% to 2% of the contract amount if their subcontracts with disadvantaged business enterprises (DBEs) exceeded 10% of the total contract value. Adarand Constructors, Inc., a white-owned construction firm, challenged the program after losing a bid to a higher bidding DBE. The program was initially upheld with lenient judicial review, but the Supreme Court later reversed the decision, rejecting the use of "intermediate scrutiny" for racial preferences. The Supreme Court rejected the use of "intermediate scrutiny" for racial preferences, requiring strict scrutiny for race-based classifications by Congress. Despite this, the Court acknowledged the need for government action to address racial discrimination. The court of appeals reviewed the constitutionality of the DOT's disadvantaged business enterprise program in Colorado, finding that the program, as currently structured without financial incentives, passed constitutional scrutiny. The federal government's interest in addressing past discrimination in government contracting was deemed compelling, and Congress had the authority to act in this regard. The federal government had a "compelling interest" in preventing and remedying past discrimination in government contracting nationwide. The appeals court clarified that the 5% and 10% goals in the program were aspirational, not mandatory, and any challenge to those provisions was outside the scope of the ruling. The revised program was found to be constitutionally superior to the pre-1996 program. The revised DOT program post-1996 was constitutionally superior to the pre-1996 program, incorporating race-neutral measures and time limits for disadvantaged businesses. The post-1996 revisions of the DOT program improved constitutionality by incorporating race-neutral measures, time limits for disadvantaged businesses, and voluntary participation for prime contractors with an express waiver option. Monetary caps on subsidies to prime contractors and a shift to a "preponderance of the evidence" standard for proof of social disadvantage further mitigated the burden on third parties. The Supreme Court declined an appeal from the Tenth Circuit ruling in Concrete Works of Colorado, Inc. v. City and County of Denver, which examined a city ordinance promoting participation by minority- and female-owned businesses in the construction industry. In 1990, Denver City Council passed Ordinance 513 to promote participation by minority- and female-owned businesses in public work projects. The ordinance established MBE and WBE participation goals on city contracts, with annual expenditure goals of 16% for MBEs and 12% for WBEs. The program was revised in 1996 and 1998, reducing the goals for MBEs and WBEs in construction contracts to 10% and prohibiting self-performed work from counting towards the goals. Concrete Works of Colorado, a construction firm owned by a white male, sued the city in 1992 for allegedly being denied contracts for not meeting the goals. The city was sued by Concrete Works of Colorado in 1992 for allegedly being denied contracts for not meeting MBE and WBE participation goals. Evidence presented at trial included disparities in minority and female utilization in construction projects, discrimination faced by M/WBEs in the industry, and the government's justification for racial and gender preferences in public contracting. The circuit court found that Denver did not need "irrefutable or definitive" proof of its own guilt in discrimination, only evidence linking its spending to discriminatory exclusion in the construction industry. Denver was not required to identify specific discriminatory practices or policies, nor prove intent to disadvantage women or minorities. Imposing such a burden would undermine reliance on statistical studies and anecdotal evidence. Croson's warning against relying on "mere societal discrimination" did not apply if discrimination in the targeted industry was shown.
